body: ATTRACTIONS Museum MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM AND GARDEN, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Built in 1799 as a carriage house for Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, it was the Mount Vernon Hotel from 1826 to 1833. Hourly candlelight tours, tonight from 6 to 8 p.m. and tomorrow from 4 to 7 p.m. Tickets: $12, $6 for members; reservations, (212)
title: SPARE TIMES

author: Frank M. Meola, who grew up in Tottenville, is at work on his first novel, ''Islanders,'' which is set on Staten Island.
body: ALVA SCHULZ often gets angry when she looks out her window. Cars roar down her narrow street, and her wood-shingle cottage, where she has lived all her 76 years, is surrounded by large new houses packed tight where woods used to be. Here in Tottenville, Staten Island's most southern and rural town, and a place that she loves, Ms. Schulz sometimes
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Closer Quarters

body: GESUALDI--Mary, in her 102nd year, of Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, on November 5th, 2003. A scholarship recipient, Mary graduated from New Rochelle College as an accomplished French teacher in the NYC Board of Education. She was fondly admired by colleagues and students at New Utrecht H.S., 1923-1964. An honorary member of Arista, Mary was a language
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GESUALDI, MARY

body: Today is Election Day. All the contests are local, so the results will affect everyday lives -- from trash removal and taxes to safe streets, good schools and clean government. For some of the most competitive races and the five questions on the New York City ballot, here are our recommendations, beginning with just this: Vote. Polls are open from
title: Choices for Election Day

body: There are 51 seats in the City Council, and all are up for grabs next Tuesday. Among the few truly competitive races, here are our choices in Brooklyn and Staten Island. Brooklyn: District 35 (Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and parts of Crown Heights, Prospect Heights and Bedford Stuyvesant) -- The contest in this district is the epilogue to the killing
title: Endorsements for the City Council

body: A group of City Council members announced a proposal yesterday to regulate cybercafes, saying the businesses were much like the video arcades of the 1980's in that they were magnets for violence and truancy. The lawmakers held a news conference yesterday to respond to instances of serious violence that began at cybercafes in southwest Brooklyn in
title: Lawmakers, Citing Violence, Seek to Regulate Cybercafes

body: The brothers Atanasov -- Dimitre, Vladimir and Alex -- grumble about their after-school lessons like typical American boys; in their case, boys who are being forced to take up to five hours a week of ballroom-style dance lessons. ''I'm there 24/7,'' said Dimitre, who will not even tell his friends at Dyker Heights Intermediate School that he spends
title: The Russians Are Coming, Stepping Lightly

body: The Dyker Heights post office in Brooklyn was abuzz with curiosity seekers yesterday morning. Did the world's newest media star live in their ZIP code? ''We heard he was from Brooklyn,'' said Lucille Lovisi, a clerk. ''Then we heard he was from Bensonhurst, then we figured, 'What are the odds he's from this area?' '' Her question was answered
title: A NATION AT WAR: SYMBOLS; Atop Statue, Marine Thrills Army of Fans Back Home

body: KATE Woolverton, 4, was home with the baby sitter when the first plane hit on Sept. 11, 2001. Her mother, Karolyn, called frantically and urged the baby sitter to stay put with Kate. But Ms. Woolverton didn't quite make it back before the first tower fell. Kate, who has light brown hair and is tall for her age, was terrified. Ash and smoke began to
title: URBAN TACTICS; A Frightened Child Versus a Rule

body: Candidates in four special elections in Brooklyn and the Bronx worked feverishly into the night yesterday, with their staffs making phone calls, putting together car pool operations and placing final touches on efforts to draw voters to the polls today. Two of the special elections are for City Council seats, one in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx,
title: 2 Council and 2 Assembly Races Go to Voters Today

body: There will be four special elections today in New York City, two of them in Brooklyn and two in the Bronx. Polling places will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. In Brooklyn, voters in Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Bensonhurst will cast ballots in a nonpartisan City Council race. And in East New York and parts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville,
title: Voting Hours for Special Elections

body: Former State Senator Vincent J. Gentile yesterday strongly defended his use of a photograph of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Upper East Side town house in literature for Mr. Gentile's campaign for a City Council seat. Mr. Gentile, a Brooklyn Democrat who is running in a special election for a vacant seat, used a full-color photograph of the mayor's
title: Council Candidate Defends Using Photo of Mayor's House

body: Voters in the City Council's 43rd District in Brooklyn go to the polls in a special election on Feb. 25 to fill the seat left vacant when Martin Golden, one of only four Republicans on the Council, was elected to the State Senate last November. The field of five candidates includes a wealth of longtime experience in the mostly working-class
title: Rosemarie O'Keefe for City Council

body: Jennifer Elyssa Gottesman, a daughter of Ellen Meyer of Long Beach, N.Y., is to be married today to David Joel Kellman, a son of Amy Kellman and Dr. Scott Kellman of Manhasset Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Sheer is to officiate at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, N.Y. The bride, 22, graduated magna cum laude from Barnard College and is a law student
title: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; Jennifer Gottesman, David Kellman
